How to Start a Free Website with Vercel, Cloudflare R2, Astro & Filament Laravel

A GV Lab Pixel-Tech Guide to Fast, Modern, Ultra-Modular Web Stacks In the era of hyper-modular development, building a modern website no longer requires heavy servers or complex DevOps. At GV Lab, we craft stacks that feel light as pixels yet powerful as engines.

Published
Jan 1, 1970

This guide walks you through creating a free-to-run website powered by:

  • Vercel â€“ frictionless frontend hosting

  • Cloudflare R2 â€“ affordable object storage

  • Astro â€“ a hybrid static + island architecture framework

  • Filament + Laravel â€“ a lightning-fast admin panel

  • GitHub + Actions â€“ automated deployment pipelines

  • DDEV â€“ local dev environment, clean & portable

Letâ€™s break it down step by step the GV-Lab way: clean workflow, pixel-sharp decisions, zero-waste code.

1. Detecting What Vercel Can Do for You

Vercel is a high-performance hosting platform with a simple mission: deploy instantly, scale automatically, pay nothing until you grow.

Why Vercel fits a pixel-tech workflow

  • âš¡ One-click deployments

  • ğŸ” Seamless GitHub connections

  • ğŸŒ Automatic global CDNs

  • ğŸ§© Perfect for Astro, Next.js, Svelte, Vue, static sites

  • ğŸ†“ Free tier for personal projects

For the frontend part of your project, Vercel is practically the ideal launchpad.
Weâ€™ll use it to host Astro and handle auto-deployment via GitHub.

2. Cloudflare R2 â€” The Smart Way to Store Images

Image and asset storage is where most â€œfree hostingâ€ projects hit limitations.
Enter Cloudflare R2:

Why Cloudflare R2 works beautifully with Vercel

  • ğŸ’¾ No egress fees (you wonâ€™t get billed for downloads)

  • ğŸª¶ S3-compatible API

  • ğŸ†“ Free tier generous for small sites

  • ğŸš€ Extremely fast through Cloudflareâ€™s global edge

Use cases in your stack

  • Astro image storage

  • Admin uploads from Filament

  • CDN-served static assets

Youâ€™ll essentially use R2 as a global image bucket that talks easily with your front-end and Laravel API.

3. What is Astro? And Why GV Lab Chooses It

Astro is a modern front-end framework designed for speed â€” not bloat.

How Astro Works

  • Ships zero JS by default

  • Supports â€œIslands Architectureâ€ â€” interactive components load only where needed

  • Can embed React, Vue, Svelte, Solid, and others inside the same project

  • Perfect for content sites, landing pages, blogs, marketing sites

Astro vs. Modern Frameworks

Astro is a precision framework â€” like pixel art: minimal, sharp, intentional.

4. Filament + Laravel â€” The Admin That Works for You

For the backend admin, Filament (built on Laravel) is the fastest way to get an admin panel thatâ€™s:

  • Clean

  • Beautiful

  • Fast to build

  • Plugin-ready

  • Fully customizable

Why Filament Fits This Stack

  • Simple forms for managing content

  • Media upload integration (Cloudflare R2 compatible via Flysystem)

  • Can be hosted cheaply or via Render/Docker

Youâ€™ll use Filament for your CMS/admin while Astro handles the frontend.

5. Step-by-Step Setup (GV Lab Edition)

Step 1 â€” Create Your GitHub Repository

  1. Go to GitHub â†’ New Repository

  2. Name it e.g. pixel-astro-admin

  3. Initialize with README

  4. Clone it locally

Step 2 â€” Initialize Astro

npm create astro@latest

Choose:

  • Template: â€œBlogâ€ or â€œMinimalâ€

  • Typescript: â€œYesâ€

  • Install dependencies: â€œYesâ€

Then push it to GitHub:

git add .
git commit -m "init astro project"
git push

Step 3 â€” Connect Astro Repo to Vercel

  1. Open Vercel

  2. â€œAdd New Projectâ€

  3. Choose your GitHub repo

  4. Vercel auto-detects Astro

  5. Deploy

Congratulations â€” your frontend is live globally in 30 seconds.

6. Step 4 â€” Auto-Deployments with GitHub Actions

Vercel automatically redeploys whenever you push changes, but you can add custom workflows if needed.

A simple sample .github/workflows/deploy.yml looks like:

name: Deploy Astro
on:
  push:
    branches: [ main ]
jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3
      - uses: pnpm/action-setup@v2
      - run: pnpm install
      - run: pnpm build

Vercel finalizes deployment automatically.

7. Step 5 â€” Build Your Laravel + Filament Backend (via DDEV)

Install Laravel with DDEV

ddev config --project-type=laravel --php-version=8.2 --create-docroot
ddev start
ddev composer create laravel/laravel .

Install Filament

ddev composer require filament/filament:"^3.0"
php artisan make:filament-user

Access your admin at:
/admin

Clean, pixel-smooth admin ready.

8. Step 6 â€” Connect Filament to Cloudflare R2

Add a new disk to config/filesystems.php:

'r2' => [
    'driver' => 's3',
    'key' => env('R2_KEY'),
    'secret' => env('R2_SECRET'),
    'region' => 'auto',
    'bucket' => env('R2_BUCKET'),
    'endpoint' => env('R2_ENDPOINT'),
],

Use this disk in Filament:

->disk('r2')

Now your admin uploads images straight to R2 with global delivery.

9. Step 7 â€” Integrating Astro with Filament API

For content from Laravel:

  • Create API routes in /routes/api.php

  • Use Astro fetch() to pull posts/products/settings

  • Cache data or generate static pages for extra speed

Astro + Laravel becomes:

  • Astro = UI/Frontend

  • Laravel = API/Admin

A perfect hybrid.
